intro: Phormium cookianum, commonly known as the Cook Island flax, is a striking plant native to the Cook Islands. It is a member of the Agavaceae family and is characterized by its tall, sword-shaped leaves that can grow up to 2 meters in length. The plant produces striking red or purple flower spikes that emerge from the base of the leaves. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular ornamental plant in tropical and subtropical regions. Its fibrous leaves have historically been used for weaving and other traditional crafts.
